body: The point of the questions is not that I don't know [many] answers to them. It is that they cannot be answered without otherwise-unnecessary metadata that almost certainly outweighs any potential savings.

Since this is not exercised in the Dataflow postcommit (sad face) I have not run it. I kicked off Flink postcommit at https://builds.apache.org/view/Beam/job/beam_PostCommit_Java_RunnableOnService_Flink/1392/

Overall concept LGTM and I'll take a peek at the code and merge shortly if I don't see any problems.

Changes Unknown when pulling **d863e6863b1487aa884151c9a317076dab8facd6 on aaltay:expand** into ** on apache:python-sdk**.

The point that I'm bringing across is that protocols already have to deal with the issue of an end of file marker and if they represent a stream of elements must encode element boundaries themselves somehow. Any protocol that doesn't follow the above is broken in some small but fundamental use case so it doesn't make sense to require objects to encode to non-zero number of bytes.
R: @tgroh
LGTM, thanks.
Thank you.

I'm going to close this. It is pointed out that when an encoding context says "outer" it actually means "tail"; it is quasi-accurately documented but just inaccurately named. So there are plenty of situations where the outer context is actually nested within a larger structure that includes adequate framing to get some savings. Given this demonstration of > 0 cases where there is a benefit, we shouldn't make this change.

I think it'd be a nicer user experience to raise the original exception, and possibly not just for the TestPipeline. I think this came up before, but in a language like Python (or Java) exceptions are the way to indicate abnormal behavior, and failing to check the status is error prone. Perhaps you could file a JIRA about this and add a TODO? 

(BTW, did we not have any tests that, say, errors in DoFns were correctly being propagated?)

Great! That must mean it has something to do with the `--no-snapshot-updates`. I don't remember how that interacts with `--update-snapshots` and why we have both. The `.travis.yml` really should be commented when weird things like that are added. Sorry for the trouble!
I think you can proceed with the worker image.

Aljoscha is currently travelling, back by next week. I am not very familiar with when exactly the PipelineOptions are used and tranferred, so I can comment only high level:

The state backend should only be needed on the client side that prepares the job to send it to the Flink cluster. After that it is stored in Flink's internal JobGraph structure anyways.

So, assuming that, it is probably fine.
